Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 08:18PM Rovergirl wrote: I had chemo for 27 weeks!!  12 weekly infusions of Taxol, and 15 weekly infusions of AC.  I too had lymphnode involvement but am a triple neg.  20 weeks is not all that uncommon for chemo. Rover
Posts.Title: Too long and aggresive? Need advice Karma76 apple

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 05:15PM Rovergirl wrote: I will have 15 doses of AC when it's all said and done.  I have completed 10 infusions so far and am on a weekly infusion schedule.  I started w/ 12 weekly infusions of taxol.  I saw a HUGE reduction in my tumor size w/ taxol and it has remained stable w/ AC but no decrease. Rover
Posts.Title: Is there a max to AC treatments? susan13 Rovergirl

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 10:58PM Rovergirl wrote: Anahat - The "Hickman" catheter is used for bone marrow transplants so you will probably get some other port.  Dr. Hickman actually inserted my port-a-cath (a power port) a few weeks ago.  I've had minimal discomfort and no problems with infusions.  Rovergirl

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 06:42PM Rovergirl wrote: I am on taxol only ..... kinda.  I am part of a clincial trial and am taking an oral dose of an investigational drug daily and have weekly infusions of taxol.  You may find more info on taxol alone but looking up chemo therapy geared toward triple negative.  What type of questions do you have?
Posts.Title: Anyone on Taxol only? leobear leobear

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2008 12:07AM Rovergirl wrote: Dolphinsac - I'm no fan of surgery either and when it comes to needles I am a Sissy with a capital "S".  You should consider meeting with your surgeon outside the operating room and talk about your concerns and fears.  Maybe total sedation is the only way for you - get an IV, go to sleep and wake up when the surgery is over.  If your current surgeon isn't willing to work with you, then it's time to go shopping for a new one.
Posts.Title: Unable to commit to surgery dolphinsac sbmolee

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 07:43PM Rovergirl wrote: Jobu - I have just completed 10 weekly infusions of AC (I will have a total of 15).  My only SE was a little nausea at the beginning but my oncol. adjusted the timing of my anti-nausea and that took care of the issue.  I started chemo w/ taxol first so I had lost my hair w/ that drug.  My muga tests (I've had two) have come back normal.  I have found AC to be quite tolerable. Rover
Posts.Title: Adriamycin - Whar are everyones side effects jobu TPPJ
My arm-my arm- always something new tomatojuice tomatojuice

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 10:55PM Rovergirl wrote: I am currently receiving neoadj. chemo and my surgery isn't scheduled until Jan. 2009!  For me the surgery is the hardest part of my bc treatment.  I understand the science behind the surgery and why's it's necessary but emotionally I'm just not there yet.  I try and educate myself on the various surgery aspects and find I overdose on info and that sends me into a melt down.  It is absolute torture knowing I have to wait 5 months to face my fears.  I try not to think about it because the surgery is so far out but it's hard.  Most of the time I try to break treatment into weeks ... what do I have to do this week and that usually helps. I can't say I'm looking forward to the surgery I think I would rather bypass it all together but I don't think that's an option.
Posts.Title: the anticipation is wrecking me justkat dlb823

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 03:04AM Rovergirl wrote: I'm having my porta-cath installed on Wed. with my first infusion to follow.  These stories are scaring me .... has anyone had a non-painful experience with the porta-cath?
Posts.Title: Port-a Cath pain? TinaLee Kicks

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 01:59AM Rovergirl wrote: I had a good experience with my port-a-cath insertion.  The staff gave me a thorough briefing on the device and the procedures.  The physician inserting the port has a port named after him -"The Hickman" used for bone marrow transplants.  I have some serious bruising but very little discomfort.  I had my first chemo infusion a few hours after the port insertion and that went well too.  Yesterday was a big day for me and I was very nervous but it overall it everything was fine.  The Seattle Cancer Care Alliance rocks.
Posts.Title: Port-a Cath pain? TinaLee Kicks

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 03:04AM Rovergirl wrote: I had my port-a-cath and first infusion yesterday.  I have serious bruising and mild discomfort from the port-a-cath and no SE from the chemo (although it's early in the game).  I am really a sissy when it comes to needles and I'm looking at 27 weeks of weekly infusions and blood draws.  So the port-a-cath was a must for me.
Posts.Title: i got my port today ekenny315 cupcake7

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 01:13AM Rovergirl wrote: Too Young - No worries about the meltdown.  You aren't the first too cry at chemo and you won't be the last.  What's important is you stand up for yourself and get what you need. I think the medical professionals are very good at treating the actual cancer but neglect the emotional / psychological aspects. You can't battle cancer and emotionally walk away unaffected.  So if you want to cry, cry.  These are challenging times.
Posts.Title: I had a meltdown at chemo today... tooyoungtohavebc Rovergirl

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 12:40PM Rovergirl wrote: LLB - I too work for the feds. and recommend getting documentation from your surgeon on when you are able to return to work.  The govt. will accept whatever date your surgeon says and unfortunately your supervisor may not like it but that's the way it is.  Give your supervisor a chance you may him/her to much more understanding than you thought.  One more thing, if you are running out of leave, sign up for the "Leave Share Donation Program", where people can donate leave to you.  Rover
Posts.Title: Mastectomy last week - expected to return to work! LiveLoveBelieve Rovergirl
